creator: alirette@sandial.com
text:
I migrated from 1.3 to 2.0.40 and followed the Migration. Everything works but
UserDir (~user) access.  The log just dhows "Server encountered an internal 
Error or Misconfiguration." The log is set to "debug"


Here's some of my configuration:

<IfModule mod_userdir.c>
    #
    # UserDir is disabled by default since it can confirm the presence
    # of a username on the system (depending on home directory
    # permissions).
    #
    # UserDir "disable"

    #
    # To enable requests to /~user/ to serve the user's public_html
    # directory, use this directive instead of "UserDir disable":
    #
    UserDir public_html
</IfModule>
.
.
ScriptAlias /cgi-bin/ "/var/www/cgi-bin/"
ScriptAlias /public_html/ "/home/*/public_html/"
.
.
AddHandler cgi-script .cgi
.
.
<Directory "/home/*/public_html">
        AllowOverride none
        Options ExecCGI FollowSymLinks
        Order allow,deny
        Allow from from all
</Directory>

I have tried various combinations of the above for the last few days 
and I am not getting this to work at all. No matter what I set any of the 
configs to I cant execute cgi scripts. html files work fine.

In the browser I am typeing this: [ servername/~User/*.cgi ]

creator: nd@perlig.de
text:
At first, 2.0.40 is quite outdated and has know security vulnerabilities, You
should update to 2.0.48, which is the current version.

And secondly, this doesn't seem to be a bug so far. What does the error log say?
Wild guess, you compiled it with suexec support -- what does the suexec.log say?

This machine came pre loaded with Linux 8.0. I didnd have to 
build anything.

/usr/sbin/httpd -V shows: '-D SUEXEC_BIN="/usr/sbin/suexec' 

Does that mean it was compiled with suexec?

I did a /usr/sbin/suexec -V and it was compiled with:
 '-D AP_LOG_EXEC=/var/log/httpd/suexec.log'
 '-D AP_USERDIR_SUFFIX=public_html
But there is no log file in /var/log/httpd/suexec.log.
Thanks!
creator: alirette@sandial.com

text:
Please report bugs in Red Hat packages to http://bugzilla.redhat.com/bugzilla/
in the first instance, unless you can reproduce a bug using a source version of
httpd.  For configuration issues, try user support forums such as
psyche-list@redhat.com or users@httpd.apache.org for help.

The RHL8.0 httpd.conf does not load mod_suexec by default; try adding

LoadModule suexec_module modules/mod_suexec.so

to httpd.conf, then use suexec.log to diagnose any further problems as André
suggests.
creator: jorton@redhat.com
alirette@sandial.com
text:
So if this was compiled in but not enabled via LoadModule is it really
disabled.  I dont need/want this module feature. Help.
